Summary and Schedule

This lesson is an introduction to anonymization of data using Python 3 and Arx-Data Anonymization Tool (Arx). The lessons assume you have prior knownledge of Python 3 but you don’t need prior knowledge of Arx. This lesson references JupyterLab but can be taught using alternative Python 3 interpreters as well (e.g., repl.it, Anaconda).

Prerequisites

  1. Learners need to understand what files and directories are, what a working directory is, and how to start a Python interpreter.

  2. Learners must install Python 3 before the class starts.

  3. Learned must install Arx Anonymization software before the class starts.

  4. Learners must get the synethtic data before class starts: please download and unzip the file data-anonymization-python.zip.

Setup Instructions Download files required for the lesson

What do you need to do to the data to randomize it?

What do you need to do to the data when using data masking?

What do you need to do to the data when using data masking?

Can you still identify the original data with noise added?

Is there a technique that protects against all attacks?

The actual schedule may vary slightly depending on the topics and exercises chosen by the instructor.

Data Sets

Download the data-anonymization-python.zip and unzip it to your Desktop

Software Setup

Details

For basic anonymization, we will use Python 3, pandas, and faker. It is assumed that you have already set up and can use Python 3 and you know how to install the two packages listed.

For more advanced anonymization, we will use Arx-Data Anonymization Tool.Arx software was chosen because it is free and open-sourced. It is licensed under the Apache LICENSE-2.0. It further uses external libraries, which have licenses that can be seen inside their respective folders.

Download and install the Arx-Data Anonymization Tool for the operating system of your choosing. Windows 64-bit, MacOS 64-bit, and Linux/GTK 64-bit are all supported.
